awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Mohandas Pillai is " Global, Non-Scattering solutions to Geometric Evolution Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California San Diego, and the sponsoring scientist is Ioan Bejenaru.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this two-year NSF postdoctoral fellowship award studied soliton dynamics for nonlinear dispersive equations. The term dispersive, in this context, refers to the fact that solutions to the equations considered can often be decomposed into constituent waves, whose frequency and wavelength are related. In the context of this research, solitons are smooth solutions to partial differential equations, which have localized energy density, and depend on various (constant) parameters. The equations considered in this project mostly concern evolution equations, in which one can prescribe initial data at a fixed value of time, and study how this initial data evolves, as time progresses. For some of the equations considered in this project, there are some results which classify the possible asymptotic forms of solutions satisfying certain constraints. For instance, parts of these results state that, if there exist globally defined solutions satisfying certain constraints, then, these solutions decompose, for large time, into soliton(s) with potentially time-dependent (non-constant) parameters, coupled to radiation, and small corrections. In this work, soliton dynamics refers to the study of the relation between the asymptotics of the soliton parameters, and the coupled radiation.

While the aforementioned results classify the possible asymptotic forms of any solutions to the equations under consideration, these results do not address the question: For which time dependent soliton parameters, and associated radiation, do there actually exist solutions which can be decomposed as above?

Intellectual Merit:

One focus of this project was to study the above question, for the energy-critical 1-equivariant wave maps problem with two-sphere target, and the quintic, critical, focusing, semilinear wave equation. For both of these nonlinear wave equations, this project constructed large classes of new solutions involving one soliton with a time-dependent parameter, coupled to radiation, plus small corrections, with an explicit relation between the soliton parameter and the coupled radiation. In addition, the PI expects that the methods used in these works will extend to other equations. These results have been submitted for publication, with one having already appeared in a reputed research journal. Similar questions were investigated for an equivariant reduction of the energy critical Yang-Mills problem with gauge group SO(4), and this work remains in progress.

Another focus of the project was to study (with collaborators mentioned below) the behavior (including possible soliton dynamics), of solutions with initial data close to a soliton, for the two-sphere valued 2-equivariant Schrodinger maps equation (with Ioan Bejenaru and Daniel Tataru) and 1-equivariant wave maps equation (with Daniel Tataru) in 2+1 dimensions. The results obtained for Schrodinger maps will be submitted for publication, while the results for wave maps are in progress.

Broader Impacts:

The PI has had mentoring sessions with a graduate student in partial differential equations, and has given five talks at a Microlocal Analysis student reading seminar. In addition, seminar talks regarding the above research have been given at multiple institutions. Finally, the PI co-organized the Analysis and PDE seminar at UC San Diego, during 2022-2023.
